is it like they say with swords, 9 out of 10 are bad ?.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Agreed. Unfortunately the base fakes greatly outnumber the legitimate betsujin Nobuie tsuba. Jim a friend of mine bought a wonderful Akasaka Nobuiye tsuba
messages.messageBody:
Agreed.

Unfortunately the base fakes greatly outnumber the legitimate betsujin Nobuie tsuba.

Jim



a friend of mine bought a wonderful Akasaka Nobuiye tsuba recently, very
nice workmanship. Not all Nobuiye tsuba if not "the" Nobuiye should be
disgarded to quickly.

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Matt,
> I haven't seen the guard in person, but here's something I wrote in
> response to an off line question a couple of weeks ago.
>
> Jim
> There were a number of makers working
> in the Edo period that signed Nobuie, often including their place of
> residence. There are guards signed Kaga, Owari, Echizen, Akasaka, etc.
> Nobuie. Sometimes the work style of a particular later guard with
> only a
> two-character signature can be tied back to one of these. I don't think
> that I have ever seen a formal kanteisho written attributing a
> two-character-signed guard to a specific regional Edo period maker,
> though.
> I have seen an NBTHK kanteisho written to "Nobuie (Edo period)" to
> show that
> it is not a forgery, but is one of the later makers. I have seen
> another
> written to "betsujin Nobuie," meaning a different person, i.e., not the
> famous maker(s). I have also seen good quality, early Edo period tsuba
> signed Nobuie fail shinsa as forgeries.
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Matt, I haven t seen the guard in person, but here s something I wrote in response to an off line question a couple of weeks ago. Jim There were a number of
messages.messageBody:
Matt,
I haven't seen the guard in person, but here's something I wrote in response to an off line question a couple of weeks ago.

Jim
There were a number of makers working
in the Edo period that signed Nobuie, often including their place of
residence. There are guards signed Kaga, Owari, Echizen, Akasaka, etc.
Nobuie. Sometimes the work style of a particular later guard with only a
two-character signature can be tied back to one of these. I don't think
that I have ever seen a formal kanteisho written attributing a
two-character-signed guard to a specific regional Edo period maker, though.
I have seen an NBTHK kanteisho written to "Nobuie (Edo period)" to show that
it is not a forgery, but is one of the later makers. I have seen another
written to "betsujin Nobuie," meaning a different person, i.e., not the
famous maker(s). I have also seen good quality, early Edo period tsuba
signed Nobuie fail shinsa as forgeries.

Most of those follow-on makers didn't try (or weren't able) to reproduce the flavor of the
iron and rim of the original guards, though. They use classic designs, but
the plate is more like typical early-mid Edo period work. It became the
fashion during the late Edo period to produce copies of the earlier style.
Some of these late works are signed by shinshinto sword smiths or Myochin
makers and can be quite nice. The two Norisuke were famous for faking
Nobuie, Yamakichibei, Yagyu, etc., guards. The way that the rim is worked
here seems like it's from that period and might even be their work. There
is a definite attempt to recreate the original style, but the result is forced and overdone.

Photos are no substitute for seeing a piece in
person. I can't see the signature very well in the photo, but the quality
of the metal and workmanship are harder to fake than a signature.





Gimei Nobuiye?

my question is how can you tell?
It looks awfully similar to the ones in the books!

And if it is indeed gimei, how old is it do we think?

Matt



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Matt and all, The book on the page you refer to is a Kanie-Nobuie exhibition piece that has a number of high quality loose plates like those shown. The book
messages.messageBody:
Matt and all,

The book on the page you refer to is a Kanie-Nobuie exhibition piece that
has a number of high quality loose plates like those shown.

The book Arnold referred to is Kyusaku Akiyama's "Nakamura Kakudaifu Nobuie
Tsuba shu [Collection of Rubbings of Nobuie's Sword Guards Belonging to
Kakudaifu Nakamura]" from 1926 and I think several reprints. Many of the
Nobuie guards we see, including Cary's that was written up in the English
edition Token Bijitsu, are in that book. All illustrations are rubbings that
Akiyama made, which are actually more useful for study than many of the
photographs we see. Many of the guards in the book were destroyed during the
war. While the current scholarship as to the generations and authenticity of
Nobuie signatures has changed since it's publication, it is still a very
useful and interesting book.

I have a copy for sale on my website, though it is a bit pricey considering
it is from Lundgren's library, and contains notes transcribed in 1964 by
Robert E. Haynes from the notes he made in 1961 while studying in Japan with
Dr. Torigoye.

Craig

Craig L. Harris Bridge of Dreams, LLC
Books from and about Asia o: 847 696-9774
www.bridgeofdreams.com c: 847-846-7701


-----Original Message-----
From: Matthew E. Hoyle [mailto:matthewhoyle@...]
Sent: Monday, January 31, 2005 3:42 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?



Hi Arnold, thanks for the response. Did you mean the book that these scans
came from? http://www.jpsword.com/files/kn/nobuiye.html
This webpage is very good for making side by side comparisons with the pix
on Mr. Weissberg's website. I think I can see the sutble differences in the
mei now, or perhaps I want to believe I can *grin*. Some more pointers in
this direction might be good for me all the same. Are there any specifics to
look for besides the 'softness'?

With regards to the Akiyama tsuba that was found, the mind boggles how it
wound up on a table at a sword show in the US among a pile of other tsuba!

Matt

Ps. I know I shouldn't ask, but who was the lucky finder?

messages.subject: 3 tsuba for contemplation - Correction
messages.msgSnippet: This last one is signed and dated. OMI JÛ TSUNA (?) HIDE. Sorry, that should be OMI no
messages.messageBody:
<http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yamato_sword/tsuba_02.jpg>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] 3 tsuba for contemplation
messages.msgSnippet: Ah well, I have enjoyed looking at these and really have no opinion on them except to say their condition is a real pity as they otherwise look like solid
messages.messageBody:
Ah well, I have enjoyed looking at these and really have no opinion on them
except to say their condition is a real pity as they otherwise look like
"solid" work. The only opinion I venture is that on tsuba No. 2 the
hitsuana are not, in fact, hitsuana. The shape is wrong IMHO. I suggest
that the openings are a design that were later filled in with silver. The
black is more likely to be remnants of black lacquer?? Ninja tsuba?? I
think not. The ninja (if indeed they existed) were comprehensively
destroyed by 1600. I do think this is the best of three put forward. There
is just "something" about the beautiful quattrefoil (??) shape...

Bestests,

Barry Thomas.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
2... This is a nice little tsuba, it is obviously made for a katana going by
the size of the nakago ana, and the crescent moon Hitsu ana ume are very
nice. We think they may have had shakudo on them, though I was wondering
if it would have been the black patina that covers silver ??. It's a
nice little piece.

73mm x 63mm x 4mm

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yamato_sword/tsuba_02.jpg

messages.subject: 3 tsuba for contemplation
messages.msgSnippet: All, I have 3 tsuba I have been asked to share with you by a friend. They are all rather interesting and as he had some questions about their origin, I said I
messages.messageBody:
All, I have 3 tsuba I have been asked to share with you by a friend.
They are all rather interesting and as he had some questions about their
origin, I said I would pass them on here to get the collective opinions
of the group.

1: This he thought may be Toshô. I thought myself, Saotome maybe. It
appears to be in the style of Nobuiye with a design of the moon, the sun
and the stars.

85mm x 79mm x 3mm.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yamato_sword/tsuba_01.jpg

2: This one has the distinction of being maybe/apparently a Ninja Tsuba.
Ok, so I myself don't believe in Ninja, not in the sense that we see
them in the films and think that if indeed, they existed past being
runners and murderers, and they used a sword, it would probably have
been pretty normal in it's shape and fittings, anyway, besides what I
think LOL.

This is a nice little tsuba, it is obviously made for a katana going by
the size of the nakago ana, and the crescent moon Hitsu ana ume are very
nice. We think they may have had shakudo on them, though I was wondering
if it would have been the black patina that covers silver ??. It's a
nice little piece.

73mm x 63mm x 4mm

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yamato_sword/tsuba_02.jpg

3: This last one is signed and dated. OMI JÛ TSUNA (?) HIDE. I think it
is Tsuna, I am pretty sure it is in fact. and dated ( hard to read the
day but I think it is ) ANSEI YONNEN NIGATSU GOHI. 5th of Feb, 1857. It
was sold as a possible "Executioners Tsuba". It is quite thick, it's
dimensions are 76mm x 69mm x 7mm and the Nakago ana is very large
supposedly making it a " one size fits all" sort of thing with I guess,
fresh Sekigane added each time.

I have no idea if that is what this was or is, as I said, we are opening
them up for discussion and would be interested in all your thoughts.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/yamato_sword/tsuba_03.jpg

Cheers and thanks for taking the time to read.

Rich Turner




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Matt, No, that signature is not correct. Look how weak it is cut. The workmanship is also not up to Nobuie s standards. The key to this sort of thing is not
messages.messageBody:
Hi Matt,



No, that signature is not correct. Look how weak it is cut. The workmanship
is also not up to Nobuie's standards. The key to this sort of thing is not
found in books, but in the palm of your hand. I think Fred is spot on, as
usual. It looks mid Edo to me. Perhaps an Owari guy.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Matthew E. Hoyle [mailto:matthewhoyle@...]
Sent: Monday, January 31, 2005 7:32 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?



Gimei Nobuiye?

http://www.nihonto.com/11.28.04.html

Mr. Weissberg evidently thinks it is gimei, my question is how can you tell?
It looks awfully similar to the ones in the books!

And if it is indeed gimei, how old is it do we think?

Matt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Last comment/observation: I get the distinct impression that all the hitsu ana on the genuine Nobuiye examples were added later. The ones on the Kuwabara look
messages.messageBody:
Last comment/observation: I get the distinct impression that all the hitsu
ana on the genuine Nobuiye examples were added later.

The ones on the Kuwabara look like they were made at the same time when the
piece was.

Correct me here if I am wrong, but weren't hitsu ana not very popular when
Nobuiye was active? Ergo they were 'hardly' put in and when they were they
were quite different in shape from the ones in the Edo period. More
elongated and oval, in the Edo period they are more "standardized" and all
look a bit the same.

A forger in the 19th cent like for example one of the Norisuke guys might
not have thought about this and put in modern looking hitsu ana out of
habit. The hitsu ana added to the genuine Nobuiye would probably have been
added after manufacture, but still much earlier than the 19th cent (maybe
beginning edo period) and would therefore look different.

Or am I being ridiculous here?

Matt



----- Original Message -----
From: "arnold frenzel" <afrenzel@...>
To: <matthewhoyle@...>; <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, January 31, 2005 7:05 PM

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Some more observations after comparing http://www.jpsword.com/files/kn/nobuiye.html to http://www.nihonto.com/11.28.04.html some more. 1. The nakago and hitsu
messages.messageBody:
Some more observations after comparing
http://www.jpsword.com/files/kn/nobuiye.html to
http://www.nihonto.com/11.28.04.html some more.

1. The nakago and hitsu ana look 'too regular and wrongly shaped' on the
Kuwabara tsuba.
2. The mei seems to be placed a bit too low in relation to the nakago ana
and the characters are slightly too far apart(?)
3. Specifically the second character looks like it is completely out of
place, much too low, nearly next to the bottom of the nakago ana. On the
genuine examples the second character is much higher up on all of them.

Does anyone have any more comments? I think this makes quite an interesting
exercise for the newbies like myself. (at least it is for me :-)

Matt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Alan, do you mean the Alexander G. Moslé collection that Sebastian Izzard exhibited in September of last year? And do you think this particular forgery was
messages.messageBody:
Hi Alan, do you mean the Alexander G. Moslé collection that Sebastian Izzard
exhibited in September of last year?

And do you think this particular forgery was done by the Shodai or Nidai
Norisuke or is that not possible to tell? Jim has an interesting example on
his webpage: http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/ono.htm

Thanks for the comment about Kuwabara and the iron tsuba. What was he most
knowledgeable on? (soft metal) Fuchi/Kashira and other soft metal fittings
of did he also "do swords"?

Matt

Ps. When is the next Christies sale from the fittings museum?

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: It is a fake, probably made by Iwata Norisuke in the 19th century, I have been told by BobHaynes that Kuwabara did not know anything about iron tsuba so be
messages.messageBody:
It is a fake, probably made by Iwata Norisuke in the 19th century, I have
been told by BobHaynes
that Kuwabara did not know anything about iron tsuba so be careful. This
piece was from the collection Sebastian Izzard bought recently.
Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Gimei Nobuiye?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi: At first glance it does look rather nice, however the mei looks tentative, soft and not quite right to me. The first thing one would what to do is to
messages.messageBody:
Hi:
At first glance it does look rather nice, however the mei looks
tentative, soft and not quite right to me. The first thing one would
what to do is to consult the book of Akiyama collected Nobuiye (title
escapes me without reference material here) which illustrates the vast
bulk of know Nobuiye out there. A few years ago a well known California
dealer was lucky enough to find one at a show, bought it and it
eventually went Juyo. Sure enough is found among the Akiyama oshigata.
You can be quite sure that if such a tsuba left Japan and were correct
the price would have at least another zero on the end, and probably an
initial digit change as well.
Arnold


>>> matthewhoyle@... 01/30/05 5:32 PM >>>

Gimei Nobuiye?

http://www.nihonto.com/11.28.04.html

Mr. Weissberg evidently thinks it is gimei, my question is how can you
tell?
It looks awfully similar to the ones in the books!

And if it is indeed gimei, how old is it do we think?

Matt
